awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: A Data-Driven Employer-Academia Partnership for Continual Computing Curricular Change
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to serve the national interest by improving the supply of well-prepared computer science professionals capable of addressing the needs of American employers in the public and private sectors.  This project intends to build a national partnership between employers and academia to help identify and mitigate gaps between the competencies of computing graduates and the expectations of potential employers.  The project will survey computer science educators and practitioners to develop a model that defines the competencies expected by potential employers.  The project team then plans to test the model at three institutions of higher education in Alabama – the University of Alabama, Tuscaloosa, Tuskegee University, and Shelton State Community College.  Finally, the project team intends to develop tools and methods for institutions to identify and implement competency-based educational approaches for computer science across the nation.  

The project plans to use three interconnected strands of evidence-based activities to institute transformational change in the involved communities.  First, a national strand will engage U.S. faculty in developing competency-based curricula informed by industry practitioner feedback.  Second, a local pilot strand intends to create transformative curricular change based on student competencies using an evidence-based change model in the three Alabama institutions.  Sociologists and computing faculty on the team will help to understand, predict, and reduce barriers to competency-based employment of computing graduates from marginalized communities in the heart of the impoverished Alabama Black Belt.  The unique perspective relative to diversity, equity, and inclusion needs should serve as a model for other computing departments.  The third strand will develop competency-based surveys for practitioners and academics to identify and refine specific competencies that are hoped to drive continual curricular change.  Outcomes, including the change process, national workshops, and experiences from the local process will help with transferability in the computing education community.  In addition to informing curricula, the project will provide valuable data for educational researchers to help close the gap between employers and higher education.  Finally, as the competency approach to curricular design is relatively new in computing and engineering disciplines, lessons from this project will have the potential to transform curricular review and design in other STEM disciplines.  The NSF IUSE: EHR Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.  Through the Institutional and Community Transformation track, the program supports efforts to transform and improve STEM education across institutions of higher education and disciplinary communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
NSF Project Outcomes Report: DEAP

Project Name: DEAP
Submitting Entity: NSPARC at Mississippi State University

The DEAP (Data-driven Educational Alignment Project) aims to improve undergraduate computing programs by focusing on the skills that matter most. This report highlights what NSPARC contributes to and achieves with the project.

Advancing Knowledge (Intellectual Merit)

Research on Computing Skills

NSPARC plays a key role in studying the U.S. labor force, especially in computing jobs. This research helps us identify important skills needed in the computing field. It also improves communication between employers and academic programs.

Our team conducted research and analysis to identify the scope of computing professions to include in the grant, the occupational skills typical of these professions, and their expected growth trajectories. Our team also played a key role in developing two surveys and facilitating data collection from computing professionals and educators to find out which workplace competencies and skills are most important on the job and in the classroom.

The NSPARC team participated in a series of expert reviews and technical consultations regarding the development and implementation of the two DEAP project surveys, providing detailed suggestions pertaining to item clarity, response category construction, intra-project survey consistencies, viable sample sizes, feasible sampling methodologies, and survey flow design.

Our team provided the initial point of contact between the DEAP Competency Team and Qualtrics, an online survey platform providing access to sampling panels for data collection efforts. NSPARC personnel participated in a series of service expectations and cost negotiations between these groups prior to survey distribution, as well as consulted with the DEAP Competency Team regarding appropriate data validation checks.

These surveys were used during the project to gather information on the extent of h alignment of the needs of employers in the computing industry with the competencies taught in postsecondary computing programs. The results will guide future annual surveys to keep academic programs updated with industry needs.

Community Engagement

NSPARC members were on three project teams (i.e., the Competency, Change, and Leadership teams) that actively engaged with employers and academic communities across the country. This helped us understand and address the gap between what employers need and what academic programs teach.

Process Improvement

NSPARC provided strategic advice to improve processes at a research university, a minority-serving institution, and a community college. Our efforts were tailored to meet the unique needs of each institution, ensuring effective curricular changes.

Broader Impacts (Social Outcomes)

Supporting Economic Development

The DEAP project helps economic development by aligning what is covered in classes with industry needs. By identifying and integrating the skills and knowledge that employers value most, DEAP prepares students to meet current and future labor market demands. This collaborative approach not only addresses the immediate needs of the computing industry but also contributes to long-term economic stability and growth by fostering a skilled and adaptable workforce.

Enhancing Educational Practices

NSPARC’s role in creating and refining surveys has a large impact on educational practices. These surveys are designed for easy updates and deployment, providing continuous feedback to academic programs. This feedback loop helps academic institutions stay relevant and effective by adapting their courses to align with industry trends and job demands. By ensuring that educational programs incorporate the competencies most valued by employers, DEAP enhances the quality and applicability of computing education. This ongoing process of assessment and adjustment helps academic institutions produce graduates who are well-prepared for the evolving job market, ultimately improving educational outcomes and student success.

Facilitating Collaboration

NSPARC’s participation in regular project meetings and collaboration with other groups has fostered a strong collaborative environment that extended beyond the core project team. NSPARC used its extensive connections to facilitate the dissemination of the surveys to relevant computing professionals. We connected other team members to additional people and organizations that could ensure insightful questions were asked and that we could understand people’s needs all while making data collection as simple as possible. This helped the core team achieve the project’s vision and goals.

Conclusion

The DEAP project, supported by NSPARC, has made significant progress in advancing knowledge and achieving its stated outcomes. Through research, community engagement, and process improvement, we have aligned educational programs with industry needs. This supports economic development, enhances educational practices, and promotes inclusivity and diversity in computing education. NSF’s investment in the DEAP project is yielding tangible and meaningful results.

 


Last Modified: 09/17/2024
Modified by: Steven M Grice
